I would make one change to the premise of this video if I could. And that is to change it from "When privacy violation is OK" to "When privacy violation is necessary". Because something can be necessary but also wrong..... those things aren't mutually exclusive.

Take the police sending decoys to business looking for places selling tobacco/alcohol to minors. Sure, they have to check the places that are definitely doing it and punish them for breaking the law. But they also have to keep tabs on law abiding stores as well so they don't have the appearance, or get into the habit, of discriminating against certain business/owners. It may not be right to go around investigating law abiding citizens..... but in this scenario it is NECESSARY.

As I understand privacy is an uneilianable fundamental human right. There are two basic spheres of law, public and private. The state is always in the public sphere and the individual is always in the private. The two cannot be mixed. The private sphere of law supersedes the public sphere. This is what is meant by, by the people for the people or the sovereignty of the state is derived by the sovereignty of the people. The state is a legal fiction. Everyone working for the state are employees tasked with upholding the public trust. There are very few instances where the public have the jurisdiction to violate ones right to privacy, usually when someone has made a complaint and a crime has been committed ( a crime needs to consist of several basic elements in order to be valid). The law says that all financial transactions are subject to contract. Contracts also have to consist of basic elements in order to be considered enforceable.
If money or property is confiscated without a contract and tax receipt. This can be construed as theft.

FFS, stop spouting the "men are overpaid" nonsense. It has been proven time and time again that the reason there is a pay gap between men and women is because women on average work fewer hours than men. Not because men are paid more per hour. If a man and a woman both earn $10 per hour but the man works 80 hour weeks while the woman works 60 hour weeks then the man will receive $800 and the woman will receive $600. Shall we then pay the woman more per hour so that she also earns $800 per week? How is this fair? Couple with this is that women typically choose careers that on average pays less (like teaching, nursing, social work etc.). Men in those same careers earn the same as the women. It's just not a high paying career. How is this hard to understand? You're a physicist and yet you can't do simple arithmetic? Or is it just easier to be a good little parrot and repeat the popular nonsense you are told to believe? Do you honestly not think that companies would have far more trouble than it's worth to pay women less? You might as well just have told me you believe in god because your ignorance in repeating this misinformation is the same and it utterly disgusts me.

Not because I want to be an insane tin-foil hat person, but lately the mouth-frothing goose-stepping antics of a particular party have really really broken all possible boundaries in search of every last shred of political control, in the ultimate clutching of pearls before the massive and inevitable demographic transition.

Not saying that this principle is Bad, but I'm just so insanely dubious that A) there isn't already more than enough information that could easily be scraped just laying out there to break all privacy rules you want to impose or B) people won't willingly give it up anyway.

There was Almost 0 reaction to the Snowden Revelations. When someone says things that are dramatically frightening and demonstrably true over and over.... And society does literally nothing to change it...

This is why some people think the Cold War never really ended. It's Mutually Assured Destruction 2: Electric Boogaloo now with a 200% diversified portfolio of Climate Disaster and Technological incompetence/negligence! Strong AI is barreling down the tracks for our heads and cybersecurity has arguably never been worse with respect to the number and proficiency of black-hat hackers.

I don't want to be bleak, I'm a scientist, which makes me a bit of a futurist, but science has never existed in a vacuum, politically, socially, economically. And all of the three forces have been taking turns either betraying or allying themselves with the progress of knowledge. Currently in the Western World I would have to say all three fsctors are neutral in the absolutely most generous interpretation, but clearly we might be looking at all three countervalances being Against scientific integrity. People in the thread mentioned P-hacking, and now we're also dealing with an absurd reliance on AI for both the construction And interpretation of data.
Bundle this with the above-considered caveats for this video and wow... We're kinda in a very dangerous position of utterly minimizing scientific progress unless it's a huge profit motive that is magically considered "viable" by whatever billionaires want to fund the venture.

Nonsense: claiming that men make more money than women who work in the same job and work the same number of hours. It's true that men make more than women, but men work longer hours and at jobs that women refuse to work (all the dirty ones - they just want nice cushy desk jobs, not any that require endurance, tolerance, or strength). Until there's women lining up to work in coal mines and repairing down power-lines in the frozen north and many other such jobs, stop with the multiply-debunked claim that men are overpaid. In my career, up to the age of 25, women make more than men in the same job (the discrimination is the opposite of what you're claiming). Their relative wages drop after that because they choose to cut back their hours or drop out of the workforce to have kids.

It's never "good" or "ok" to violate people's rights. But the facts are we do plenty of bad things either because we feel like it or because we have a good ends in mind. When conducting a study that will reveal information about people who didn't participate in that study, recognize that what you're doing has good and bad aspects. It's like killing one person to save two. It's wrong, you probably shouldn't do it. But society will say it's okay and you can make up a reason to justify your actions so you can sleep better at night.

gender pay gap come on.

There are a lot of comments regarding the gender pay gap.
I will make an effort to explain the gender pay gap, and suggest a potential solution to it.

Before I start, I must state that the statistics referenced in this video do not concern the gender pay gap, but rather state that men are more likely to be overpaid. I am not going to debate this particular statistic because it is not referenced, so I cannot read the details. (Through conjecture I can speculate that one of the contributing factors is that men are more likely to hold leadership positions.)

Now, about that gender pay gap. I’ll be focusing on a common definition of the world (Western Europe, North America, Australia, New Zealand).
In these nations there is a significant difference in income based on genders. (1)

If you factor out differences in profession and work-hours, the gender pay gap persists. It shrinks, but in countries such as the U.S., after factoring out variables, women earn 0.86 relative value (0.72 before factoring variables) (2) compared to a male working the same profession for the same amount of hours, having served the same amount of time in employment. This statistic is true across the western world, as major meta-analysis shows. (3, 4)

There are many theories proposed to explain this discrepancy. Some state that women are less likely to ask for a raise relative to men. However, looking at the gender pay gap in STEM fields, we can see that the wage increases stagnate for women until they are in their mid 30s, before they rise at the same rate as men. (5)

The reason for this can be explained by employers fearing costs associated with childbirth, such as maternity leave and maternity pay.
This theory is backed up by looking at Iceland. The nation has a gender pay gap of 0.94 relative value (0.86 before factoring variables) (2), which ranks the best in the world. One of the contributing factors to this may be that Iceland has three months of maternity leave, three months of paternity leave and three months that the parents are free to divide among themselves. (6) For employers, this means that one gender does not carry a greater risk than the other. (7) Similar data from other Nordic nations further backs up this theory.

*In conclusion*, there may be many factors contributing to the gender pay gap. It is real, even when statistics factor out variables. It does seem that instituting equal parental leave between the sexes has strong positive effects on reducing this gap among women under 40. (2)



1. Blau FD. Understanding International Differences in the Gender Pay Gap.107.
2. Forum WE. The Global Gender Gap Report 2014.
3. Weichselbaumer D. A META-ANALYSIS OF THE INTERNATIONAL GENDER WAGE GAP. Journal of Economic Surveys.484.
4. Jarrell TDSaSB. Gender Wage Discrimination Bias? A Meta-Regression Analysis. The Journal of Human Resources.33:984.
5. Broyles P. The gender pay gap of STEM professions in the United States. International Journal of Sociology.
6. Kaul H. Gender Inequality and Care Leave in the Nordic Countries. Acta Sociologica.
7. Taskula JL. Politicising Parenthood in Scandinavia: Gender Relations in Welfare States.

My company's pension plan provide tables of data, including average salary for various groups (age and years of service). And most people know who is in which group. The plan admins won't reveal the average salary for any group that has only one member, because that would be too revealing. But for groups with two members, they will publish the average salary (e.g. $320k/year) of that group (even of just two). But for someone who is in a group of two, then they can know the precise salary of the other member in the same group (x =($320k*2)-$140k=$500k). Which is quite funny, because it's such a FAIL.

Really, one can't extract a single value for X out of a statistical average.


There is a 50% chance that when you flip a coin it will land head up. That doesn't mean that the next coin flip you make will land heads up, or that after having a coin land tails up it's guaranteed to land heads up. We can't tell anything about how the next coin toss will land, only predict how tens or hundreds of coin tosses will compare with each other.


In that same way, survey's don't actually violate individual privacy, as a good statistician will know that they can't use their statistical averages to look into the lives of individuals. They can only know the trends of the crowd as a whole.

I usually find disliking a video extremely juvenile, but spreading a debunked myth (the wage gap) on a proportadly scientific channel is a breach of the scientific way, and the fact that you just gloss over it is worse.

I don't mind different opinions, but we should be referencing blatantly incorrect conspiracies like this, it's irresponsible.

But how is that violating privacy in and of itself? I cannot see this as a violation of privacy. So what if you know my birthday is in a specific month? So what if you know I'm more prone to do something? It doesn't mean you know me and that's privacy. And that, is never okay to violate in any way shape or form.


But there is another discussion to be had here. What is privacy? What makes something private private? And sorry to say this, that is something completely subjective. Some people think sex is a private thing, then you have pornstars. Some people think birthdays are private, then you have celebrities (and they have the least amount of privacy (when the average joe considers it) in the world). I say first define privacy to the average joe. Then make criteria for said privacy studies: How many people have to believe the same privacy criteria for it to be valued as "average", those kinds of things. And do that after you have all the numbers, that way you can more effectively crunch those numbers.


I'll be honest, I dislike how certain studies are done then represented as facts when there are no criteria for the studies. Let's look at smoking for example. We all know that it can cause cancer (keyword, can). But how do we know that? Looking at the death-toll by cause of lung-cancer? But then you have to consider pollution and the sorts. Maybe by looking at the lifestyle of smokers? But then you have to consider what the average lifestyle is among them. And then the factors change from smoking to either the pollution or the lifestyle. And when everything is considered and there is no more room for criteria to add, you can find the numbers of death by smoking. And then you don't come with a certainty. No, what we are presented with is percentages. We know it destroys lungs, we see pictures of that. But some have lived a life that's full. And then that's called anecdotal evidence. Anomalies if you will. They are not considered because they are deemed bad evidence.

I'm digressing a little but it all holds some value. My point is that studies have an inherent flaw of forgetting to give context on certain subjects because we think cancer bad. And while I agree that cancer bad, we cannot stop considering certain facts because we deem it as bad evidence. In my book, evidence is evidence.



The problem with all this is that people don't think for themselves and just go with it because title means everything to them. You could be a saint sent from heaven to tell us (first of all that it exists lol) everything that is bad for us. I want proof of that though. Irrefutable proof of that. And a study isn't what's gonna prove that to me, not without the proper context. Like, the big bang. It has been proven through calculations that I could actually follow along with. Simple reasoning for that is that there are no negative consequences for humanity from that. So we get to hear about it. The higgs boson, gravity, black holes, the sun and earth, nature, all of these things have credible studies done on them. But once it concerns cancer, suddenly context flies out the window somewhat.



And here's why this all matters to me. Humanity, is not something we can judge, objectify or place value on because we are invaluable. We are priceless. We are imperfect and different under any and every circumstance. We can find averages but that doesn't even come close to finding out who or what we are in the slightest. The only way we can do that is by living. And if you need smoking or alcohol or any other substance, religion, ideology or what have you, by all means live. You are not my boss but guess what, neither am I yours. So stop believing studies because it came from a scientist, they're human too, they could be wrong and not know it. Just live your life the way you feel like doing so. As long as it doesn't negatively impact another's life too much, I'm okay with it.



Now to end off, let me clarify what I mean by negatively impact and I'll be done here. I mean that you shouldn't physically harm others unless they do that to you. Even then, try not to. An eye for an eye leaves the whole world blind. I'm too far gone for that lesson, you may not be. When it comes to emotional damage. Truth can hurt too so that's a little more vague. As long as you don't manupilate others, I say do what you feel is right. I could say don't bully people, but are you gonna listen to that? I'm sure you're not gonna. Not even on purpose either. I say go ahead but make sure that you don't make someone kill themselves. And that's a whole different argument. If you're willing to have that argument, I'm right here so ask away. As for mental damage, emotional damage is somewhat linked to that as I eluded to with the bullying comment. This is a no go from me. If you harm someone in any way mentally, you are the bad guy. Not necessarily a bad person, just that it's your fault. You can choose to do with that what you will but I really believe you need to own up to that and take responsibility. To give an example, I know way too many children that turned into adults at age 16 or lower because of household troubles. I know I did. That's not when you should be an adult, not in this day and age. Anyway, I believe that will do for now.


TL;DR, live how you want and don't let others tell you how to. And studies are not always truth, merely satisfaction for a set of truths that can form a lie together if not handled carefully.


I sincerely hope that if you read all of this, you at least try to understand me. And if you still don't understand, ask me. I'm not here to attack anyone or anything. I merely wanted to point out a flaw and state my reason for why it is a flaw. The privacy thing was merely a catalyst for it. Have a nice day ^^ And sorry for making you read this entire beast XD

Gotta say, I don't think the second type should qualify to be privacy to begin with, since the information revealed is not inherently linked to a private person. If the study showed hockey players are 100% guaranteed to have their birthdays in January, then publishing that study isn't violating their privacy, as it's not linked to them, but rather their profession. What I mean by that is, that the privacy violation would take place when revealing them to be hockey players (against their will), not by publishing a general correlation. The risk for the so called "privacy violation" would be taken by them the moment they decide to be publicly known as a hockey player.
